column3: My little doves-let me call you so, for you are very like them, those pretty blue birds, at this minute as I look at your good dear faces.

column2: People talk to you a great deal about your education, but some good, sacred memory, preserved from childhood, is perhaps the best education.
column3: People talk to you a great deal about your education, but some good, sacred memory, preserved from childhood, is perhaps the best education.

column2: If a man carries many such memories with him into life, he is safe to the end of his days, and if one has only one good memory left in one's heart, even that may sometime be the means of saving us.

column2: Perhaps we may even grow wicked later on, may be unable to refrain from a bad action, may laugh at men's tears and at those people who say as Kolya did just now, 'I want to suffer for all men,' and may even jeer spitefully at such people.

column2: That will be so, I understand you, Karamazov! cried Kolya, with flashing eyes.

column3: The boys were excited and they, too, wanted to say something, but they restrained themselves, looking with intentness and emotion at the speaker.

column2: I say this in case we become bad, Alyosha went on, "but there's no reason why we should become bad, is there, boys?
column3: I say this in case we become bad, Alyosha went on, "but there's no reason why we should become bad, is there, boys?

column2: Let us be, first and above all, kind, then honest and then let us never forget each other!

column2: I give you my word for my part that I'll never forget one of you.
column3: I give you my word for my part that I'll never forget one of you.

column2: Every face looking at me now I shall remember even for thirty years.

column3: Just now Kolya said to Kartashov that we did not care to know whether he exists or not.

column3: May his memory live for ever in our hearts from this time forth!"
